definition: **Mitochondrial ribosomes** are the <u>protein synthesis machinery inside mitochondria</u>. They are similar to bacterial ribosomes in structure and origin - in fact, mitochondrial ribosomes in eukaryotic cells are about **55S particles (in mammals, composed of a 28S small subunit and a 39S large subunit)** which function like prokaryotic 70S ribosomes. Mitochondrial ribosomes <u>translate a few proteins encoded by mitochondrial DNA</u>, mostly components of the oxidative phosphorylation system.
tips: **Endosymbiotic evidence:** The <u>similarity of mitochondrial ribosomes to bacterial 70S ribosomes</u> supports the theory that mitochondria evolved from an engulfed bacterium.

**Antibiotic sensitivity:** Some antibiotics that inhibit bacterial ribosomes (e.g., chloramphenicol) can <u>also affect mitochondrial protein synthesis</u> because of the ribosomal similarity, which can explain certain drug side effects on human cells.

Mitochondrial protein synthesis is limited - human mitochondrial DNA only encodes **13 proteins**, so mitoribosomes specialize in making those (mostly subunits of the respiratory complexes). The majority of proteins in mitochondria are made by <u>cytosolic 80S ribosomes and imported</u>.
exam_appearance: Endosymbiosis question - If asked for evidence that mitochondria were once bacteria, an answer is: -<u>Mitochondria have their own circular DNA and 70S-type ribosomes similar to bacteria</u>.-

Antibiotic trap - A question might ask why a bacteriostatic antibiotic can impact eukaryotic cells: the answer could be that it targets 70S ribosomes and thus can also <u>interfere with mitochondrial ribosomes</u>, affecting mitochondrial protein production.

Structure ID - Mitochondrial ribosomes are not visible under normal microscopy in typical textbooks, but know the term -<u>55S mitoribosome</u>- refers to the mitochondrial protein-making complex (distinct from the 80S cytoplasmic ribosome).
